column1: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia is an infection of the lungs that can occur in people who have a suppressed immune system.

Most humans are exposed to CMV in their lifetime, but typically only individuals with weakened immune systems become ill from CMV infection Serious CMV infections can occur in people with weakened immune systems from conditions such as: - AIDS - Bone marrow transplant - Chemotherapy or other treatments that suppress the immune system - Organ transplant In people who have had organ and bone marrow transplants, the risk of infection is greatest 5 - 13 weeks after the transplant.
The doctor or nurse will perform a physical exam.
Some people with CMV pneumonia will need to get medication through a vein (intravenously).
Low oxygen levels in the blood in people with CMV pneumonia often predicts death, especially in patients who need to be placed on a breathing machine.

Complications of CMV infection in people with AIDS include spread of disease to other parts of the body: - CMV pneumonia - Esophageal disease - Intestinal disease - Inflammation of the retina (CMV retinitis) Complications of CMV pneumonia include: - Kidney impairment (from drugs used to treat the condition) - Low white blood cell count (from drugs used to treat the condition) - Overwhelming infection that doesn't respond to treatment - Return of CMV infections
Call your health care provider if you have symptoms of CMV pneumonia.

The following procedures have been shown to help prevent CMV pneumonia in certain patients: - Using organ transplant donors who don't have CMV - Using CMV-negative blood products for transfusion - Using CMV-immune globulin in certain patients Preventing AIDS avoids certain other diseases, including CMV, that can occur in people who have a weakened immune system.
